course.subject: LANG
course.name: Cantonese for Non-Chinese Language Background Students I
course.description: This course is restricted to students with non-Chinese language backgrounds who are beginners in the learning of Cantonese. It equips students with Cantonese communicative competence necessary for living and net-working in Hong Kong, thus facilitating their smooth integration into the local community. The learning activities involve developing students' listening and speaking skills in an attempt to build learners' confidence and fluency in using Cantonese for daily communication.

reviews.author: rg108
reviews.title: Embark on your Cantonese Learning Journey
reviews.comment_content:
The class covers 9 units that are taught out of order but build upon each other in a way that makes sense. The 9 units are taught in the following sequence:

Unit 1: Nice to meet you
Unit 2: Do you speak Cantonese?
Unit 6: Have you eaten yet?
Unit 3: When will you...
Unit 5: Where are you going?
Unit 7: Let's go Yum Cha
Unit 8: What is your favourite pass time?
Unit 9: See what I have bought...
Unit 4: Hello, can I speak to...
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor teaches the content very well and ensures that everyone speaks and practices the dialogues and vocabulary. The professor frequently engages the class with breakout room activities where we have to come up with our answers to certain questions and report our preferences to the class. It's great that everyone has to turn on their camera because it fosters greater interaction and a more engaging classroom environment. Ultimately the class is fun because even though classes are currently on zoom and thus can lead to zoom fatigue, the classes feel energising.
reviews.comment_workload: The overall workload is light. There are usually 2 assignments every week. A listening task and a speaking task. They don't take very long and are fun to do. Every so often there is a bigger assessment such as recording a video of yourself talking about your daily routine (Assessment 1) or content related to the 9 units (Part of Assessment 3). Assessment 2 is a 1000 word Project Report written in English on an aspect of Hong Kong culture. Assessment 3 consists of a 1-1 conversation with the professor, a role play and a 1.5 minute video recording discussing your project research and related to the 9 units. Finally, as the professor engages the class and offers ample opportunities for participation. This part of the grading scheme is the simplest to obtain. Just come to class ready to practice your Cantonese!

reviews.author: AnnaNiN
reviews.comment_content:
9 Units.
Different topic for each unit with new vocab & grammar, and cultural notes.
As follows:
1. Nice to meet you
2. Do you speak Cantonese?
3. Have you eaten yet?
4. When will you …?
5. Where are you going?
6. Let’s go yum cha!
7. What is your favourite pastime?
8. See what I have bought!
9. Telephone calls
reviews.comment_teaching: Everyone gets an opportunity to speak & ask questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading for the listening assesment is fair, you can get some answers wrong and still get the top mark.
Harder to get high marks in speaking etc.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is more than you would think, at least one assignment per week, usually listening, with a 1000 word research project at the end, a role play in class and an oral exam.

reviews.author: ust_student
reviews.comment_content: The content is basic but it really is not interesting. The worst part is that there are students who join this course with prior knowledge in Cantonese. These students tend to answers all the questions in class while the beginners do not get a chance to. And answering questions account for participation marks. So be aware of this before you join the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is nice. Her accent is also quite strong so it is difficult to understand. Overall she is quite chill and fun.
reviews.comment_grading: The professor is quite lenient when it comes to grading.
reviews.comment_workload: Way too much. There is an assignment to submit every week. There is a 1000 words report,  two video recorded speeches, group project. There is also one on one conversation with the professor at the end of the sem.

reviews.author: Fionaaw
reviews.title: Too many workload
reviews.comment_content: Cantonese in everyday life in general
reviews.comment_teaching: The online teaching is kind of not good, and some of the student say that they never learn mandarin or cantonese but actually they have a background in it and if the grading are bell-curve so the one who are still really newbie and doesn't know any of it were done. Or sometimes the teacher will prefer to choose the same person in every lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: bell-curve maybe, for me it is not good within a lot of workloads in one lesson
reviews.comment_workload: every week either you have to submit a video or recording to canvas for speaking, and include a written assignment, with a 1000 words essay in the end of the course. 2 videos that graded high.

reviews.author: TimTam
reviews.title: Good professor but language doesn't stick
reviews.comment_content:
There are 9 units spread out in one semester:

Unit 1: Nice to meet you
Unit 2: Do you speak Cantonese?
Unit 6: Have you eaten yet?
Unit 3: When will you...
Unit 5: Where are you going?
Unit 7: Let's go Yum Cha
Unit 8: What is your favourite pass time?
Unit 9: See what I have bought...
Unit 10: Hello, can I speak to...
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher does her best engaging with the students. Also, we did our classes on Zoom despite in-person classes are now allowed. It doesn't help when some students are not showing their faces in class nor reciting.
reviews.comment_grading: The teacher doesn't show the final grading.
reviews.comment_workload: There are small assignments every week. If you're the type of person who doesn't like consistent assignments, however small, don't take this course.
